frameDefinitions: An Arguer presents a Content, along with Support, to an Addressee.
An Agent has done or omitted to do an Act or is responsible for the obtaining of a State_of_affairs, which a Judge deems to constitute a violation of an obligation or a moral guideline.
The Support, a phenomenon or fact,  lends support to a claim or proposed course of action, the Proposition, where the Domain_of_relevance may also be expressed.
A Communicator conveys a Message to an Addressee; the Topic and Medium of the communication also may be expressed.
A Gambler commits an Asset to a prediction that an Uncertain_situation will have a particular Outcome (or class of outcomes).
This frame contains verbs and nouns that communicate the act of a Speaker to address a Message to some Addressee using language.
frameExamples: Jan <t>argued</t> that the evidence was inadmissable.
Kim failed to fully <t>justify</t> his decision.
The latest poll results <t>show</t> that support of the president is at an all-time low.
Let's hope it did n't have time to <t>communicate</t> any of its findings to its overlords.
I now <t>declare</t> you members of this Society.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Arguer</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to entertain the <fen>Content</fen>, which can be a proposition to be believed or a course of action to be taken, based on the <fen>Support</fen> presented.
The <fen>Arguer</fen> presents the <fen>Content</fen> before the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The Time at which an <fen>Arguer</fen> makes an argument for the <fen>Content</fen>.
This role identifies the location where an argument is made by an <fen>Arguer</fen>.
The person or organization that  is held responsible for a prior <fen>Act</fen> or for a <fen>State_of_affairs</fen>.
An action  for which the <fen>Agent</fen> is held responsible, frequently one that the <fen>Agent</fen> has taken themself.
A <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> that the Agent is held responsible for.
The <fen>Time</fen> of the justifying event.
Support is a fact that lends epistemic support to a claim, or that provides a reason for a course of action. Typically it is expressed as an External Argument.
This is a belief, claim, or proposed course of action to which the Support lends validity. Normally it is expressed as a Finite Clause Complement:
The sentient entity that uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey a <fen>Message</fen> to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
<fen>Message</fen> is a proposition or set of propositions that the <fen>Communicator</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to believe or take for granted.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
The physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The time at which the communication takes place.
The location where the act of communication occurs.
The person who wages the <fen>Asset</fen> on a certain Outcome.
Something desirable possessed by or directly associated with the <fen>Gambler</fen> which is lost if the <fen>Gambler</fen> loses the wager.
The <fen>Gambler</fen> predicts that a certain <fen>Outcome</fen> will hold.
The <fen>Gambler</fen> predicts how an <fen>Uncertain_situation</fen> will resolve.
The time when the <fen>Gambler</fen> makes the wager.
The place where the <fen>Gambler</fen> makes the wager.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that produces the <fen>Message</fen> (whether spoken or written).  It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target	</t> word, or as the Genitive modifier of the noun.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.  It can be expressed as a clause or as a noun phrase.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the statement.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Message</fen> is made.
The role specifies the location where the <fen>Message</fen> takes place.
listRoleExamples: Jan argued <fex>that the evidence was inadmissable</fex>.
<fex>Jan</fex> argued that the evidence was inadmissable.
The government argued <fex>in August</fex> that the prisoners should not be released
The young men will be arguing their policies <fex>in the school auditorium</fex>.
<fex>Smithers</fex> defended his decision by insisting that he had used his best judgment
Kim failed  to fully justify <fex>his decision</fex>.
The lawyers tried  to justify <fex>enormous punitive damages being paid to victims on a first-past-the-post system</fex> .
<fex>The fact that you lied to me</fex> shows that I shouldn't trust you.
The fact that you lied to me shows <fex>that I shouldn't trust you</fex>.
<fex>He</fex> finds it hard to communicate with people, not least his separated parents .
How do you communicate to them <fex>that you really like them</fex> ?
Had someone communicated to the capital <fex>about the flagrant disregard of the religious law</fex> ?
Opinions are usually communicated <fex>over the telephone</fex> and are often given within 24 hours.
Evelyn said <fex>that she was not ready to leave</fex>.
Kim preached to me <fex>over the phone</fex>.
In some remarks <fex>at the National Press Club</fex>, Mr. Keating said he would make a better prime minister tha nMr. Hawke.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the University of California at Berkeley
